bboxes.raw_text:
The family of Mr.. and Mrs.
John W. Lewis held a reunion
recently. Mr.. Lewis. is retired
government employee. He and his
wife reside, at 1926 E. Adams.
He was formerly employed with
the post office department and
has been retired for six years.


Mrs Lewis celebrated her
e3rd birthday and their ten chill
dren attended.


Those attending the reunion
we're Eddie. Of Berkeley; John,
Of Phoenix: P. C. of Show Low:
Earle, Cecilia. Arvetta. George,
Charles, James, and Addie, all
of Texas.

Monday Boys baseball game
Class B = 6 pm.


Free movie at bandShell
Tuesday Crafts $3.50 pm.
Slimnastics 7p.m.; Adult Crafts
5 pm. Teen queen benefit dance
June 10 8 pm.
Wcdne Sday Drama lessons 1-2
pm. Tap dance lessons 10 am.
Sat.


Day camp is now open for child
rem ages seven to twelve.

NEW YORK - Eleven picketS
from civil rights and other groups
were arrested last Thur sday as
they staged a sit-in at the South
African Mission to the UN. They
were protesting political trials
and jailings in South Africa.


@Take your CORE and NAACP
and get out of here" spluttcrpd
South African Amba SSadOr
Matthys Botha to reporters. He
repeatedly had contacted Us AM
basSador Adlai Stevenson in an
effort to avoid an international
incident. The demonstration
we're finally arrested after
4-hOur Sit-in.


The sit-ln was part of a larger
demonstration organized by the
American Committee on Africa
and sponsored by CORE, NAACP.
Student Non-Violent Coordinating
Committee, United Automobile
Workers, Local 1899, Drug and
Hospital Employees, Student Act
ion Committee Of Union Semin-
airy, Students for a Democratic
Society, US National Student As
sociation, American Society of
African Culture, Campus Ameri-
cans for Democratic Action and
y sociation of Artists for
Freedom.


A crowd of $50 pickets chanted
freedom slogans and songs on
the Madison Avenue pavement
while the angry South African
representatives we're deciding on
their course of action. Demon
strators then marched a mile
to the United Nations for a rally.


James Farmer, CORE National
Director, told the demonstrators
that "the moose destined for the
neck of Nelson Mandela must
hang empty" and "must be trans
formed into an economic moose
around the neck of the apartheid

NEW YORK - an raising
$50. 900 for the United Negro
College Funds Developm e Mt
Campaign. business men have
demonstrated their sense of res
possibility for improving educa-
ton for Negro youth, to help
qualify more of them for the
higher level positions opening up
in our increasingly sophistica
society,"


Charles G. Mortimer, chair

man, General Foods Corporation,
made this statement at a luncheon
given in his honor by the United
Negro College Fund at the Har-
ward Club today.


Mortimer accepted a scroll
presented from the fund schools
by DR.. Albert W. Dent, vice.
chairman of the Funds board
Of directors and president of
billiard University, New Orleans,
LOui Siana.
